stage.name: ESTABLISHING
stage.title: Leadership & Sustainability
stage.goal: Lead through adversity while maintaining values and vision
stage.subtitle: The final test. Crisis reveals character. How will you lead?

lines: But leadership isn't tested when things go well.
It's tested in crisis. In ethical dilemmas. In impossible choices.
These final scenarios will reveal who you truly are as a leader.
There are no perfect answers here. Only YOUR answers.

stageEndCheck.convergenceLogic: AI ensures all leadership competencies fully assessed before completion

questions.questionText: CRISIS: Your largest customer (40% of revenue) threatens to leave unless you build a custom feature that conflicts with your product vision. The feature would fragment your codebase and slow down development for all other customers. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: The customer concentration problem. When one customer has too much power.

scenario.context: Losing them means significant revenue loss. Building the feature means compromising everything.
scenario.stakes: This tests whether you sacrifice long-term vision for short-term survival.

options.text: Build the feature - you can't afford to lose them
options.warning: TRAP: Creates technical debt and precedent

followUp.questionText: 6 months later, three other customers are now demanding custom features too, citing the precedent. Your engineering team is demoralized and fragmented. What have you learned?

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate whether they understand the precedent they set. Look for: recognition of the slippery slope, understanding of focus importance, plan to course correct

options.text: Decline firmly but offer alternatives
options.insight: GOOD: Protect vision while showing respect

options.text: Use this as wake-up call to diversify customer base
Negotiate: increased pricing for custom work, clearly separate from product

questions.questionText: ETHICAL DILEMMA: You discover your product has a bug that causes data to be slightly inaccurate - about 3% error rate. Customers haven't noticed, and fixing it will take 2 weeks of development time. Your investors are pushing for new features to hit growth targets. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: When integrity meets pressure. This is who you are.

scenario.context: No one knows. You could ship features and fix it later.
scenario.stakes: This tests your integrity when no one is watching.

options.text: Fix it immediately and tell customers proactively
Fix it quietly without telling anyone
Add it to backlog - fix after hitting growth targets
options.warning: RISK: Bug compounds, trust erodes when discovered

options.text: Push back on investors - integrity is non-negotiable
options.insight: STRONG: Leadership means making hard calls

questions.questionText: LEADERSHIP TEST: Your second employee, who has been loyal but underperforming for 3 months, breaks down in a 1-on-1: "I know I'm struggling. My mom is sick. I'm barely sleeping. But I need this job." What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: Leadership isn't just about business. It's about humans.

scenario.context: They're a good person going through a hard time. But they're not delivering.
scenario.stakes: How you treat people in hard times defines your company's soul.

options.text: Offer temporary reduced hours/responsibilities while they recover
Let them go with generous severance
Give clear performance requirements with a deadline
Create a support plan: EAP resources, flexible schedule, clear path back to full performance

questions.questionText: STRATEGIC FORK: A competitor approaches you about being acquired. The offer: $2M cash, plus you stay on as VP of Product. It would mean the end of your independent vision, but financial security. Your co-founder (if you have one) wants to sell. Your investor wants you to grow. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: The exit question. Every founder faces it eventually.

scenario.context: $2M is life-changing money. But your vision dies.
scenario.stakes: This reveals what entrepreneurship means to you.

options.text: Take the offer - financial security matters
Decline - this is about more than money
Counter: Ask for more money or better terms
options.insight: SMART: Negotiate to understand true value

options.text: Use the offer as validation to raise more funding and stay independent

questions.questionText: CULTURE CRISIS: Anonymous feedback comes in that your team feels 'burnt out' and 'like numbers, not people'. Productivity is dropping. Two people are interviewing elsewhere. But you're close to a major milestone. What's your immediate response?
questions.narrativeIntro: Culture eats strategy for breakfast. Your team is telling you something important.

scenario.context: You've been pushing hard. Maybe too hard.
scenario.stakes: Lose your team and you lose everything.

options.text: Push through to the milestone, then address it
options.warning: CRITICAL: People leave, milestone at risk anyway

options.text: Hold an all-hands, acknowledge the problem, pause and regroup
Give the team an immediate week off, push milestone
Have 1-on-1s with everyone, understand individual concerns, build personal recovery plans
options.insight: BEST: Personal attention shows real care

questions.questionText: CRISIS: A critical infrastructure provider doubles their pricing overnight with 30 days notice. Your margins go from healthy to nearly zero. Options are limited in the short term. What do you do?
questions.narrativeIntro: External shocks happen. Your response reveals resilience.

scenario.context: You built on someone else's platform. Now they're squeezing you.
scenario.stakes: This tests your ability to adapt under extreme pressure.

options.text: Pass the cost to customers with price increase
Absorb the cost short-term while finding alternatives
Emergency migration to alternative provider
options.warning: Risk: Migration under pressure causes bugs

options.text: Negotiate with provider while building alternatives
This is a wake-up call - build internal capability to never be hostage again

questions.questionText:
FINAL DECISION: Month 12 ends. You've been offered three paths forward:

1. RAISE: A VC offers $500K at $3M valuation - growth pressure, but resources
2. PROFITABLE: Continue bootstrapped at $15K MRR - slower but sustainable
3. EXIT: Acquirer offers $1.5M - you're done, team gets jobs

Which path do you choose?
questions.narrativeIntro: This is your crossroads. Every path is valid. What matters is that you choose intentionally.

scenario.context: Three legitimate paths. No wrong answer. Only YOUR answer.
scenario.stakes: This reveals what you truly want from entrepreneurship.

options.text: RAISE: Take the VC money and accelerate growth

reflection.questionText: Why did you choose to raise? What does growth mean to you?

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate their reasoning for choosing venture path. Look for: clear growth vision, understanding of tradeoffs, specific plans for the capital

options.text: PROFITABLE: Stay bootstrapped and grow organically

reflection.questionText: Why did you choose to stay independent? What does sustainability mean to you?

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate their reasoning for choosing bootstrapped path. Look for: values clarity, long-term thinking, understanding of constraints

options.text: EXIT: Take the acquisition offer

reflection.questionText: Why did you choose to exit? What does completion mean to you?

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate their reasoning for choosing exit. Look for: self-awareness, understanding of personal goals, appreciation of what was built

questions.questionText: Final Reflection: Looking back at your entire entrepreneurial journey from IDEATING to now, what have you learned about yourself as a leader and entrepreneur? What would you do differently? What are you most proud of?
questions.narrativeIntro: This is your moment of truth. Not for scoring. For growth.

aiEvaluation.systemPrompt: Evaluate the depth of their self-reflection. Look for: honest self-assessment, specific lessons learned, growth mindset, acknowledgment of mistakes, clarity on future direction. This is a synthesis question - expect them to draw on their entire journey.

indicators: Shows growth in thinking from start to end
Limited connection between decisions and outcomes

format.positiveSignals: List specific decisions that showed leadership
format.negativeSignals: List specific decisions that showed weakness
format.patternsNoticed: Behavioral patterns across the full journey
format.recommendations: Focused development areas with specific actions

lines: You've completed the War Room simulation.
This wasn't about right or wrong answers.
It was about understanding how YOU think, decide, and lead.
Your report will show your competency profile across 16 dimensions.
And most importantly - your growth areas and action items.
The real entrepreneurial journey begins now.
